entities.description: Maria Alekseyevna Ouspenskaya was a Russian actress and acting teacher. She achieved success as a stage actress as a young woman in Russia, and as an elderly woman in Hollywood films.

heading: Births
txt: Don Marquis, American author, poet, and playwright (d. 1937)

entities.title: Don Marquis
entities.description: Donald Robert Perry Marquis was an American humorist, journalist, and author. He was variously a novelist, poet, newspaper columnist, and playwright. He is remembered best for creating the characters Archy and Mehitabel, supposed authors of humorous verse. During his lifetime he was equally famous for creating another fictitious character, "the Old Soak," who was the subject of two books, a hit Br

heading: Births
txt: Porfirio Barba-Jacob, Colombian poet and author (d. 1942)

entities.title: Porfirio Barba-Jacob
entities.description: Miguel Ángel Osorio Benítez, better known by his pseudonym, Porfirio Barba-Jacob, was a Colombian poet and writer.

heading: Births
txt: Benito Mussolini, Italian fascist revolutionary and politician, 27th Prime Minister of Italy (d. 1945)

entities.title: Prime Minister of Italy
entities.description: The President of the Council of Ministers of the Italian Republic, commonly referred to in Italy as Presidente del Consiglio or informally as Premier, and known in English as the Prime Minister of Italy, is the head of government of the Italian Republic. The office of Prime Minister is established by Articles 92 through 96 of the Constitution of Italy. The Prime Minister is appointed by the Presid

heading: Births
txt: Ralph Austin Bard, American financier and politician, 2nd Under Secretary of the Navy (d. 1975)

entities.title: Ralph Austin Bard
entities.description: Ralph Austin Bard was a Chicago financier who served as Assistant Secretary of the Navy, 1941–1944, and as Under Secretary, 1944–1945. He is noted for a memorandum he wrote to Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson in 1945 urging that Japan be given a warning before the use of the atomic bomb on a strategic city. He was "the only person known to have formally dissented from the use of the atomic bomb w

entities.title: Under Secretary of the Navy
entities.description: The Under Secretary of the Navy is the second-highest ranking civilian official in the United States Department of the Navy. The Under Secretary, called the "Under" in Pentagon slang, reports to the Secretary of the Navy (SECNAV). Before the creation of the Under Secretary's office, the second-highest civilian at the Department of the Navy was the Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

heading: Births
txt: Theda Bara, American actress (d. 1955)

entities.title: Theda Bara
entities.description: Theda Bara was an American silent film and stage actress.

heading: Births
txt: Sigmund Romberg, Hungarian-American pianist and composer (d. 1951)

entities.title: Sigmund Romberg
entities.description: Sigmund Romberg was a Hungarian-born American composer. He is best known for his musicals and operettas, particularly The Student Prince (1924), The Desert Song (1926) and The New Moon (1928).

heading: Births
txt: Vladimir K. Zworykin, Russian-American engineer, invented the Iconoscope (d. 1982)

entities.title: Vladimir K. Zworykin
entities.description: Vladimir Kosmich Zworykin was a Russian-American inventor, engineer, and pioneer of television technology. Zworykin invented a television transmitting and receiving system employing cathode ray tubes. He played a role in the practical development of television from the early thirties, including charge storage-type tubes, infrared image tubes and the electron microscope.

entities.title: Iconoscope
entities.description: The iconoscope was the first practical video camera tube to be used in early television cameras. The iconoscope produced a much stronger signal than earlier mechanical designs, and could be used under any well-lit conditions. This was the first fully electronic system to replace earlier cameras, which used special spotlights or spinning disks to capture light from a single very brightly lit spot.

heading: Births
txt: Bernhard Zondek, German-Israeli gynecologist and academic (d. 1966)

entities.title: Bernhard Zondek
entities.description: Bernhard Zondek was a German-born Israeli gynecologist who developed the first reliable pregnancy test in 1928.

heading: Births
txt: William Powell, American actor and singer (d. 1984)

entities.title: William Powell
entities.description: William Horatio Powell was an American actor. A major star at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, he was paired with Myrna Loy in 14 films, including the Thin Man series based on the Nick and Nora Charles characters created by Dashiell Hammett. Powell was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Actor three times: for The Thin Man (1934), My Man Godfrey (1936), and Life with Father (1947).

heading: Births
txt: Maria L. de Hernández, Mexican-American rights activist (d. 1986)

entities.title: Maria L. de Hernández
entities.description: María Rebecca Latigo de Hernández was a Mexican-American rights activist. She was born in San Pedro Garza García, Mexico. During the 1930s, she spoke publicly and demonstrated on behalf of Mexican Americans about their education in the United States. She and her husband, Pedro Hernandez Barrera, founded Orden Caballeros de America on January 10, 1929. She organized the Asociación Protectora de Mad

heading: Births
txt: Neil Ritchie, Guyanese-English general (d. 1983)

entities.title: Neil Ritchie
entities.description: General Sir Neil Methuen Ritchie, was a British Army officer who saw service during both the world wars. He is most notable during the Second World War for commanding the British Eighth Army in the North African campaign from November 1941 until being dismissed in June 1942. Despite this, his career did not end. Richie later commanded XII Corps throughout the campaign in Northwest Europe, from Jun

heading: Births
txt: Isidor Isaac Rabi, American physicist and academic, Nobel Prize Laureate (d. 1988)

entities.title: Isidor Isaac Rabi
entities.description: Isidor Isaac Rabi was an American physicist who won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1944 for his discovery of nuclear magnetic resonance, which is used in magnetic resonance imaging. He was also one of the first scientists in the United States to work on the cavity magnetron, which is used in microwave radar and microwave ovens.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Births
txt: Walter Beall, American baseball player (d. 1959)

entities.title: Walter Beall
entities.description: Walter Esau Beall was an American baseball player who played for the New York Yankees on several championship teams in the 1920s.

heading: Births
txt: Mary V. Austin, Australian community worker and political activist (d. 1986)

entities.title: Mary V. Austin
entities.description: Dame Mary V. Austin was an Australian community worker and political activist. The daughter of Admiral Percival Hall-Thompson and his wife, Helen, she was educated in New Zealand at Marsden College, Wellington.

heading: Births
txt: Eyvind Johnson, Swedish novelist and short story writer, Nobel Prize Laureate (d. 1976)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Births
txt: Teresa Noce, Italian labor leader, activist, and journalist (d. 1980)

heading: Births
txt: Don Redman, American composer, and bandleader (d. 1964)

heading: Births
txt: Mahasi Sayadaw, Burmese monk and philosopher (d. 1982)

entities.title: Mahasi Sayadaw
entities.description: Mahāsī Sayādaw U Sobhana was a Burmese Theravada Buddhist monk and meditation master who had a significant impact on the teaching of vipassanā (insight) meditation in the West and throughout Asia.

heading: Births
txt: J. R. D. Tata, French-Indian pilot and businessman, founded Tata Motors and Tata Global Beverages (d. 1993)

entities.title: Tata Motors
entities.description: Tata Motors Limited is an Indian multinational automotive manufacturing company headquartered in Mumbai, Maharashtra, India. It is a part of Tata Group, an Indian conglomerate. Its products include passenger cars, trucks, vans, coaches, buses, sports cars, construction equipment and military vehicles.

entities.title: Tata Global Beverages
entities.description: Tata Consumer Products is an integrated Food & Beverage company headquartered in Mumbai, Maharashtra, India and a subsidiary of the Tata Group. It is amongst the Top 10 Food & Beverage companies in India with a vision to become a multi-category FMCG major. Tata Consumer Products is world's second-largest manufacturer and distributor of tea and a major producer of coffee.

heading: Births
txt: Clara Bow, American actress (d. 1965)

entities.title: Clara Bow
entities.description: Clara Gordon Bow was an American actress who rose to stardom during the silent film era of the 1920s and successfully made the transition to "talkies" in 1929. Her appearance as a plucky shopgirl in the film It brought her global fame and the nickname "The It Girl". Bow came to personify the Roaring Twenties and is described as its leading sex symbol.

heading: Births
txt: Dag Hammarskjöld, Swedish economist and diplomat, 2nd Secretary-General of the United Nations, Nobel Prize Laureate (d. 1961)

entities.title: Secretary-General of the United Nations
entities.description: The Secretary-General of the United Nations is the chief administrative officer of the United Nations and head of the United Nations Secretariat, one of the six principal organs of the United Nations.

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Births
txt: Stanley Kunitz, American poet and translator (d. 2006)

heading: Births
txt: Thelma Todd, American actress and singer (d. 1935)

entities.title: Thelma Todd
entities.description: Thelma Alice Todd was an American actress and businesswoman who was often referred to by the nicknames "The Ice Cream Blonde" and "Hot Toddy". Appearing in around 120 feature films and shorts between 1926 and 1935, she is best remembered for her comedic roles opposite ZaSu Pitts, and in films such as Marx Brothers' Monkey Business and Horse Feathers and a number of Charley Chase's short comedies.

heading: Births
txt: Melvin Belli, American lawyer (d. 1996)

entities.title: Melvin Belli
entities.description: Melvin Mouron Belli was a prominent United States lawyer, author, and actor known as "The King of Torts" and by insurance companies as "Melvin Bellicose". He had many celebrity clients, including Zsa Zsa Gabor, Errol Flynn, Chuck Berry, Muhammad Ali, The Rolling Stones, Jim Bakker and Tammy Faye Bakker, Martha Mitchell, Maureen Connolly, Lana Turner, Tony Curtis, and Mae West. During his legal car

heading: Births
txt: Samm Sinclair Baker, American author (d. 1997)

entities.title: Samm Sinclair Baker
entities.description: Samm Sinclair Baker was the author/co-author of many how-to and self-help books, most notably The Complete Scarsdale Medical Diet which he co-authored with Dr. Herman Tarnower.

heading: Births
txt: Chester Himes, American-Spanish author (d. 1984)

heading: Births
txt: Gale Page, American actress (d. 1983)

entities.title: Gale Page
entities.description: Gale Page was an American singer and actress.

heading: Births
txt: Foster Furcolo, American lawyer and politician, 60th Governor of Massachusetts (d. 1995)

entities.title: Foster Furcolo
entities.description: John Foster Furcolo was an American lawyer, writer, and Democratic Party politician from Massachusetts. He was the state's 60th governor, and also represented the state as a member of the United States House of Representatives. He was the first Italian-American governor of the state, and an active promoter of community colleges.

entities.title: Governor of Massachusetts
entities.description: The Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, is the head of state and head of government of Massachusetts and is charged with enforcing state laws. The governor is the chief of the executive branch of the government of Massachusetts and is the commander-in-chief of the commonwealth's military forces.

heading: Births
txt: Archbishop Iakovos of America (d. 2005)

heading: Births
txt: Erich Priebke, German war criminal, leader of the 1944 Ardeatine massacre (d. 2013)

entities.title: Erich Priebke
entities.description: Erich Priebke was a German mid-level SS commander in the SS police force (SiPo) of Nazi Germany. In 1996, he was convicted of war crimes in Italy, for commanding the unit which was responsible for the Ardeatine massacre in Rome on 24 March 1944 in which 335 Italian civilians were killed in retaliation for a partisan attack that killed 33 men of the German SS Police Regiment Bozen. Priebke was one

entities.title: Ardeatine massacre
entities.description: The Ardeatine massacre, or Fosse Ardeatine massacre, was a mass killing of 335 civilians and political prisoners carried out in Rome on 24 March 1944 by German occupation troops during the Second World War as a reprisal for the Via Rasella attack in central Rome against the SS Police Regiment Bozen the previous day.

heading: Births
txt: Irwin Corey, American actor and activist (d. 2017)

entities.title: Irwin Corey
entities.description: "Professor" Irwin Corey was an American stand-up comic, film actor and activist, often billed as "The World's Foremost Authority". He introduced his unscripted, improvisational style of stand-up comedy at the San Francisco club the hungry i. Lenny Bruce described Corey as "one of the most brilliant comedians of all time."

heading: Births
txt: Bruce R. McConkie, American colonel and religious leader (d. 1985)

entities.title: Bruce R. McConkie
entities.description: Bruce Redd McConkie was a member of the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints from 1972 until his death. McConkie was a member of the First Council of the Seventy of the LDS Church from 1946 until his calling to the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles.

heading: Births
txt: Francis W. Sargent, American soldier and politician, 64th Governor of Massachusetts (d. 1998)

entities.title: Governor of Massachusetts
entities.description: The Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, is the head of state and head of government of Massachusetts and is charged with enforcing state laws. The governor is the chief of the executive branch of the government of Massachusetts and is the commander-in-chief of the commonwealth's military forces.

heading: Births
txt: Budd Boetticher, American director, producer, and screenwriter (d. 2001)

entities.title: Budd Boetticher
entities.description: Oscar "Budd" Boetticher Jr. was an American film director. He is most famous for a series of low-budget Westerns he made in the late 1950s starring Randolph Scott.

heading: Births
txt: Charlie Christian, American guitarist (d. 1942)

heading: Births
txt: Rupert Hamer, Australian politician, 39th Premier of Victoria (d. 2004)

entities.title: Premier of Victoria
entities.description: The Premier of Victoria is the head of government in the Australian state of Victoria. The Premier is appointed by the governor of Victoria, and is the leader of the political party able to secure a majority in the Victorian Legislative Assembly.

heading: Births
txt: Rochus Misch, German SS officer (d. 2013)

entities.title: Rochus Misch
entities.description: Rochus Misch was a German Oberscharführer (sergeant) in the 1st SS Panzer Division Leibstandarte SS Adolf Hitler (LSSAH). He was badly wounded during the Polish campaign during the first month of World War II in Europe. After recovering, from 1940 to April 1945, he served in the Führerbegleitkommando as a bodyguard, courier, and telephone operator for German dictator Adolf Hitler.

entities.title: SS
entities.description: The Schutzstaffel was a major paramilitary organization under Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party in Nazi Germany, and later throughout German-occupied Europe during World War II. It began with a small guard unit known as the Saal-Schutz made up of party volunteers to provide security for party meetings in Munich. In 1925, Heinrich Himmler joined the unit, which had by then been reformed and given its

heading: Births
txt: Don Ingalls, American writer and producer (d. 2014)

entities.title: Don Ingalls
entities.description: Donald G. Ingalls was an American screenwriter and television producer. He was a lifelong friend of Gene Roddenberry, having served in the Los Angeles Police Department with him.

heading: Births
txt: Edwin O'Connor, American journalist and author (d. 1968)

heading: Births
txt: Mary Lee Settle, American novelist, essayist, and memoirist (d. 2005)

heading: Births
txt: Neville Jeffress, Australian businessman (d. 2007)

entities.title: Neville Jeffress
entities.description: Neville Jeffress was an Australian advertising executive and the founder of Media Monitors Australia, now called Isentia.

heading: Births
txt: Richard Egan, American actor (d. 1987)

entities.description: Tuoba Huang (拓拔晃), Xianbei name Tianzhen (天真), formally Crown Prince Jingmu (景穆太子), later further formally honored as Emperor Jingmu (景穆皇帝) with the temple name Gongzong (恭宗) by his son Emperor Wencheng, was a crown prince of the Chinese/Xianbei dynasty Northern Wei. He was the oldest son of Emperor Taiwu, and was created crown prince in 432 at the age of four, and as he grew older, Emperor Taiwu

entities.title: Northern Wei
entities.description: The Northern Wei, also known as the Tuoba Wei (拓跋魏), Later Wei (後魏), was a dynasty founded by the Tuoba (Tabgach) clan of the Xianbei, which ruled northern China from 386 to 534 AD, during the period of the Northern and Southern dynasties. Described as "part of an era of political turbulence and intense social and cultural change", the Northern Wei dynasty is particularly noted for unifying northe

heading: Deaths
txt: Offa of Mercia (b. 730)

entities.title: Offa of Mercia
entities.description: Offa was King of Mercia, a kingdom of Anglo-Saxon England, from 757 until his death. The son of Thingfrith and a descendant of Eowa, Offa came to the throne after a period of civil war following the assassination of Æthelbald. Offa defeated the other claimant, Beornred. In the early years of Offa's reign, it is likely that he consolidated his control of Midland peoples such as the Hwicce and the M

heading: Deaths
txt: Li Shen, chancellor of the Tang Dynasty

entities.title: Li Shen
entities.description: Li Shen (李紳), courtesy name Gongchui (公垂), formally Duke Wensu of Zhao (趙文肅公), was an official of the Chinese dynasty Tang Dynasty, serving as a chancellor during the reign of Emperor Wuzong. He was also noted as a poet.

entities.title: Chancellor of the Tang dynasty
entities.description: The chancellor was a semi-formally designated office position for a number of high-level officials at one time during the Tang dynasty. This list includes chancellors of the reign of Wu Zetian, which she referred to as the "Zhou dynasty" (周), rather than "Tang" (唐).

heading: Deaths
txt: Olaf II of Norway (b. 995)

entities.title: Olaf II of Norway
entities.description: Olaf II Haraldsson, later known as Saint Olaf, was King of Norway from 1015 to 1028. Son of Harald Grenske, a petty king in Vestfold, Norway, he was posthumously given the title Rex Perpetuus Norvegiae and canonised at Nidaros (Trondheim) by Bishop Grimkell, one year after his death in the Battle of Stiklestad on 29 July 1030. His remains were enshrined in Nidaros Cathedral, built over his burial

heading: Deaths
txt: Ladislaus I of Hungary (b. 1040)

entities.title: Ladislaus I of Hungary
entities.description: Ladislaus I or Ladislas I, also Saint Ladislaus or Saint Ladislas was King of Hungary from 1077 and King of Croatia from 1091. He was the second son of King Béla I of Hungary. After Béla's death in 1063, Ladislaus and his elder brother, Géza, acknowledged their cousin, Solomon as the lawful king in exchange for receiving their father's former duchy, which included one-third of the kingdom. They co

heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Urban II (b. 1042)

entities.title: Pope Urban II
entities.description: Pope Urban II, otherwise known as Odo of Châtillon or Otho de Lagery, was the head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States from 12 March 1088 to his death. He is best known for initiating the Crusades.

heading: Deaths
txt: Philip I of France (b. 1052)

entities.title: Philip I of France
entities.description: Philip I, called the Amorous, was King of the Franks from 1060 to 1108. His reign, like that of most of the early Capetians, was extraordinarily long for the time. The monarchy began a modest recovery from the low it reached in the reign of his father and he added to the royal demesne the Vexin and Bourges.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ingeborg of Denmark, Queen of France (b. 1175)

entities.title: Ingeborg of Denmark, Queen of France
entities.description: Ingeborg of Denmark was Queen of France by marriage to Philip II of France. She was a daughter of Valdemar I of Denmark and Sofia of Minsk.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Óg de Burgh, 2nd Earl of Ulster (b. 1259)

entities.title: Richard Óg de Burgh, 2nd Earl of Ulster
entities.description: Richard Óg de Burgh, 2nd Earl of Ulster and 3rd Baron of Connaught, called The Red Earl, was one of the most powerful Irish nobles of the late 13th and early 14th centuries.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Stanley, 1st Earl of Derby (b. 1435)

entities.title: Thomas Stanley, 1st Earl of Derby
entities.description: Thomas Stanley, 1st Earl of Derby, KG was an English nobleman and traitor to King Richard III of England. He was stepfather of King Henry VII of England. He was the eldest son of Thomas Stanley, 1st Baron Stanley and Joan Goushill.

heading: Deaths
txt: Martin Behaim, German-Bohemian geographer and astronomer (b. 1459)

entities.title: Martin Behaim
entities.description: Martin Behaim, also known as Martin von Behaim and by various forms of Martin of Bohemia, was a German textile merchant and cartographer. He served John II of Portugal as an adviser in matters of navigation and participated in a voyage to West Africa. He is now best known for his Erdapfel, the world's oldest surviving globe, which he produced for the Imperial City of Nuremberg in 1492.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Caius, English physician and academic (b. 1510)

entities.title: John Caius
entities.description: John Caius, also known as Johannes Caius and Ioannes Caius, was an English physician, and second founder of the present Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacques Bongars, French scholar and diplomat (b. 1554)

entities.title: Jacques Bongars
entities.description: Jacques Bongars was a French scholar and diplomat.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Urban VIII (b. 1568)

entities.title: Pope Urban VIII
entities.description: Pope Urban VIII, born Maffeo Barberini, was head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States from 6 August 1623 to his death in 1644. As pope, he expanded the papal territory by force of arms and advantageous politicking, and was also a prominent patron of the arts and a reformer of Church missions.

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Warren, Irish admiral and politician (b. 1703)

entities.title: Peter Warren (Royal Navy officer)
entities.description: Admiral Sir Peter Warren, KB was a British naval officer from Ireland who commanded the naval forces in the attack on the French fortress of Louisbourg, Nova Scotia in 1745. He later sat as MP for Westminster.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Kies, German astronomer and mathematician (b. 1713)

entities.title: Johann Kies
entities.description: Johann Kies was a German astronomer and mathematician. Born in Tübingen, Kies worked in Berlin in 1751 alongside Jérôme Lalande in order to make observations on the lunar parallax in concert with those of Nicolas Louis de Lacaille at the Cape of Good Hope.

heading: Deaths
txt: René Nicolas Charles Augustin de Maupeou, French lawyer and politician, Chancellor of France (b. 1714)

entities.title: René Nicolas Charles Augustin de Maupeou
entities.description: René Nicolas Charles Augustin de Maupeou was a French lawyer, politician, and chancellor of France, whose attempts at reform signalled the failure of enlightened despotism in France. He is best known for his effort to destroy the system of parlements, which were powerful regional courts, in 1770–74. When King Louis XV died in 1774, the parlements were restored and Maupeou lost power.

entities.title: Chancellor of France
entities.description: In France, under the Ancien Régime, the officer of state responsible for the judiciary was the Grand Chancellor of France. The Chancellor was responsible for seeing that royal decrees were enrolled and registered by the sundry parlements, provincial appellate courts. However, since the Chancellor was appointed for life, and might fall from favour, or be too ill to carry out his duties, his duties

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Andoche Junot, French general (b. 1771)

entities.title: Jean-Andoche Junot
entities.description: Jean-Andoche Junot, 1st Duke of Abrantes was a French military officer during the Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Wilberforce, English philanthropist and politician (b. 1759)

entities.title: William Wilberforce
entities.description: William Wilberforce was a British politician, philanthropist, and a leader of the movement to abolish the slave trade. A native of Kingston upon Hull, Yorkshire, he began his political career in 1780, eventually becoming an independent Member of Parliament (MP) for Yorkshire (1784–1812). In 1785, he became an evangelical Christian, which resulted in major changes to his lifestyle and a lifelong co

heading: Deaths
txt: Gaspard de Prony, French mathematician and engineer (b. 1755)

entities.title: Gaspard de Prony
entities.description: Baron Gaspard Clair François Marie Riche de Prony was a French mathematician and engineer, who worked on hydraulics. He was born at Chamelet, Beaujolais, France and died in Asnières-sur-Seine, France.

heading: Deaths
txt: Franz Xaver Wolfgang Mozart, Austrian pianist, composer, and conductor (b. 1791)

entities.title: Franz Xaver Wolfgang Mozart
entities.description: Franz Xaver Wolfgang Mozart, also known as Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Jr., was the youngest child of six born to Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and his wife Constanze. He was the younger of his parents' two surviving children. He was a composer, pianist, conductor, and teacher of the late classical period whose musical style was of an early Romanticism, heavily influenced by his father's mature style.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Schumann, German composer and critic (b. 1810)

entities.title: Robert Schumann
entities.description: Robert Schumann was a German composer, pianist, and influential music critic. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest composers of the Romantic era. Schumann left the study of law, intending to pursue a career as a virtuoso pianist. His teacher, Friedrich Wieck, a German pianist, had assured him that he could become the finest pianist in Europe, but a hand injury ended this dream. Schumann th

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Dick, Scottish minister, astronomer, and author (b. 1774)

entities.title: Thomas Dick (scientist)
entities.description: Reverend Thomas Dick, was a British church minister, science teacher and writer, known for his works on astronomy and practical philosophy, combining science and Christianity, and arguing for a harmony between the two.

heading: Deaths
txt: Agostino Depretis, Italian politician, 9th Prime Minister of Italy (d. 1813)

entities.title: Agostino Depretis
entities.description: Agostino Depretis was an Italian statesman and politician. He served as Prime Minister of Italy for several stretches between 1876 and 1887, and was leader of the Historical Left parliamentary group for more than a decade. He is the fourth-longest serving Prime Minister in Italian history, after Benito Mussolini, Giovanni Giolitti and Silvio Berlusconi. Depretis is widely considered one of the mos

entities.title: Prime Minister of Italy
entities.description: The President of the Council of Ministers of the Italian Republic, commonly referred to in Italy as Presidente del Consiglio or informally as Premier, and known in English as the Prime Minister of Italy, is the head of government of the Italian Republic. The office of Prime Minister is established by Articles 92 through 96 of the Constitution of Italy. The Prime Minister is appointed by the Presid

heading: Deaths
txt: Vincent van Gogh, Dutch painter and illustrator (b. 1853)

entities.title: Vincent van Gogh
entities.description: Vincent Willem van Gogh was a Dutch post-impressionist painter who posthumously became one of the most famous and influential figures in the history of Western art. In a decade, he created about 2,100 artworks, including around 860 oil paintings, most of which date from the last two years of his life. They include landscapes, still lifes, portraits and self-portraits, and are characterised by bold

heading: Deaths
txt: Floriano Peixoto, Brazilian general and politician, 2nd President of Brazil (b. 1839)

entities.title: Floriano Peixoto
entities.description: Floriano Vieira Peixoto, born in Ipioca, nicknamed the "Iron Marshal", was a Brazilian soldier and politician, a veteran of the Paraguayan War, and the second President of Brazil. He is the first Vice President of Brazil to have succeeded a former President mid-term.

entities.title: President of Brazil
entities.description: The president of Brazil, officially the President of the Federative Republic of Brazil or simply the President of the Republic, is both the head of state and the head of government of Brazil. The president leads the executive branch of the federal government and is the commander-in-chief of the Brazilian Armed Forces. The presidential system was established in 1889, upon the proclamation of the re

heading: Deaths
txt: Umberto I of Italy (b. 1844)

entities.title: Umberto I of Italy
entities.description: Umberto I, nicknamed the Good, was the King of Italy from 9 January 1878 until his assassination on 29 July 1900.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marie Adam-Doerrer (b. 1838)

entities.title: Marie Adam-Doerrer
entities.description: Marie Adam-Doerrer was a Swiss women's rights activist and unionist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tobias Asser, Dutch lawyer and jurist, Nobel Prize Laureate (b. 1838)

entities.title: Tobias Asser
entities.description: Tobias Michael Carel Asser was a Dutch lawyer and legal scholar of Jewish background.

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Deaths
txt: Ernest William Christmas, Australian-American painter (b. 1863)

entities.title: Ernest William Christmas
entities.description: Ernest William Christmas was an Australian painter, known primarily for his landscapes. Much of his later, most familiar work was done outside of Australia; in Europe, South America and, finally, Hawaii.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sotirios Krokidas, Greek educator and politician, 110th Prime Minister of Greece (b. 1852)

entities.title: Sotirios Krokidas
entities.description: Sotirios G. Krokidas was an interim Prime Minister of Greece in 1922. He was a law professor in Athens.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Greece
entities.description: The prime minister of the Hellenic Republic, colloquially referred to as the prime minister of Greece, is the head of government of the Hellenic Republic and the leader of the Greek Cabinet. The incumbent prime minister is Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who took office on 8 July 2019.

heading: Deaths
txt: Didier Pitre, Canadian ice hockey player (b. 1883)

entities.title: Didier Pitre
entities.description: Joseph George Didier "Cannonball" Pitre was a Canadian professional ice hockey player. Nicknamed "Cannonball," he was renown for having one of the hardest shots during his playing career. One of the first players to join the Montreal Canadiens, Pitre and his teammates' French-Canadian heritage led to the team being nicknamed the Flying Frenchmen.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nikolai Krylenko, Russian lawyer, jurist, and politician, Prosecutor General of the Russian SFSR (b. 1885)

entities.title: Nikolai Krylenko
entities.description: Nikolai Vasilyevich Krylenko was an Old Bolshevik and Soviet politician. Krylenko served in a variety of posts in the Soviet legal system, rising to become People's Commissar for Justice and Prosecutor General of the Russian Soviet Federated Socialist Republic. He was executed during the Great Purge.

entities.title: List of Prosecutor Generals of Russia and the Soviet Union
entities.description: This is a list of Prosecutors General of Russia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joe Fry, English race car driver (b. 1915)

entities.title: Joe Fry
entities.description:
Joseph Gibson Fry was a British racing driver and distant member of the Fry's Chocolate family. 
He became the primary driver for the highly successful Shelsley Special "Freikaiserwagen", created by his cousin David Fry and Hugh Dunsterville, with help from Dick Caesar. The original car was built in Bristol in 1936 and featured an Anzani engine which was replaced in 1937 by a Blackburne engine. Jo

heading: Deaths
txt: Ali Sami Yen, Turkish footballer and manager, founded Galatasaray S.K. (b. 1886)

entities.title: Ali Sami Yen
entities.description: Ali Sami Yen, born Ali Sami Frashëri was an Albanian-Turkish sports official best known as the founder of the Galatasaray Sports Club. After the enactment of law on family names in 1934, he took the surname Yen, which literally means "win" in the Turkish language.

entities.title: Galatasaray S.K.
entities.description: Galatasaray Spor Kulübü is a Turkish sports club based on the European side of the city of Istanbul in Turkey. Most notable for its association football department, the club also consists of various other departments including basketball, wheelchair basketball, volleyball, water polo, handball, athletics, swimming, rowing, sailing, judo, bridge, motorsport, equestrian, and chess. Galatasaray S.K.

heading: Deaths
txt: Coen de Koning, Dutch speed skater (b. 1879)

entities.title: Coen de Koning
entities.description: Coen de Koning was a speed skater and cyclist. He started his sports career as a cyclist, but switched to speed skating and became the second Dutch speed skater to win a world title, in 1905. He finished second in 500 m, and won the 1500, 5000 and 10,000 m events. De Koning won the national all-around title in 1903, 1905 and 1912, and set national records in the 500 m and 10,000 m in 1905; these r

heading: Deaths
txt: Hasan Saka, Turkish politician, 7th Prime Minister of Turkey (b. 1885)

entities.title: Hasan Saka
entities.description: Hasan Saka was a Turkish politician, Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Prime Minister of Turkey.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Turkey
entities.description: The Prime Minister of the Republic of Turkey was the head of government of the Republic of Turkey from 1920 to 2018, who led a political coalition in the Turkish Parliament and presided over the cabinet. Throughout the political history of Turkey, functions and powers of the post had changed occasionally.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ronald Fisher, English biologist and statistician (b. 1890)

entities.title: Ronald Fisher
entities.description: Sir Ronald Aylmer Fisher was a British statistician, geneticist, and academic. For his work in statistics, he has been described as "a genius who almost single-handedly created the foundations for modern statistical science" and "the single most important figure in 20th century statistics". In genetics, his work used mathematics to combine Mendelian genetics and natural selection; this contributed

heading: Deaths
txt: Leonardo De Lorenzo, Italian-American flute player and educator (b. 1875)

heading: Deaths
txt: Vean Gregg, American baseball player (b. 1885)

entities.title: Vean Gregg
entities.description: Sylveanus Augustus "Vean" Gregg was born April 13, 1885, in Chehalis, Washington. For three years, the left-hander was one of the most dominant pitchers in the major leagues.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johnson Aguiyi-Ironsi, Nigerian general and politician, 2nd Head of State of Nigeria (b. 1924)

entities.title: Johnson Aguiyi-Ironsi
entities.description: Major General Johnson Thomas Umunnakwe Aguiyi-Ironsi MVO, MBE was the first Military Head of State of Nigeria. He seized power amidst the ensuing chaos following the 15 January 1966 military coup, which decapitated the country's leadership.

entities.title: List of heads of state of Nigeria
entities.description:
This is a list of the heads of state of Nigeria, from Nigeria's independence in 1960 to the present day.
Nigeria became a federal republic under the Constitution of 1963 and the monarch and Governor-General were replaced by a ceremonial President.

entities.title: John Barbirolli
entities.description: Sir John Barbirolli, CH, né Giovanni Battista Barbirolli, was a British conductor and cellist. He is remembered above all as conductor of the Hallé Orchestra in Manchester, which he helped save from dissolution in 1943 and conducted for the rest of his life. heading: Deaths
txt: Norm Smith, Australian footballer and coach (b. 1915)

entities.title: Norm Smith
entities.description: Norman Walter "Norm" Smith was an Australian rules football player and coach in the Victorian Football League (VFL). After 200 games as a player with Melbourne and Fitzroy, Smith began a twenty-year coaching career, including a fifteen-year stint at Melbourne. Recognised as the father of modern Australian football coaching, Smith coached Melbourne to six premierships and in 1996 was chosen as the

heading: Deaths
txt: Roger Williamson, English race car driver (b. 1948)

heading: Deaths
txt: Cass Elliot, American singer (b. 1941)

entities.title: Cass Elliot
entities.description: Cass Elliot, better known as Mama Cass, was an American singer and actress who is best known for having been a member of the Mamas and the Papas. After the group broke up, she released five solo albums. In 1998, she was posthumously inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame for her work with the Mamas and the Papas.

entities.title: Mickey Cohen
entities.description: Meyer Harris "Mickey" Cohen was a gangster and entrepreneur based in Los Angeles during the mid-20th century.

entities.description: Andrzej Bogucki was a Polish television, stage and film actor, as well as operetta singer and songwriter, sometimes referred to as "The Polish Chevalier".

entities.description: Herbert Marcuse was a German-American philosopher, sociologist, and political theorist, associated with the Frankfurt School of critical theory. Born in Berlin, Marcuse studied at the Humboldt University of Berlin and then at Freiburg, where he received his PhD. entities.title: Robert Moses
entities.description: Robert Moses was an American public official who worked mainly in the New York metropolitan area. Known as the "master builder" of mid-20th century New York City, Long Island, Rockland County, and Westchester County, he is sometimes compared to Baron Haussmann of Second Empire Paris, and was one of the most polarizing figures in the history of United States urban development. entities.title: Northern State Parkway
entities.description: The Northern State Parkway is a 28.88-mile-long (46.48 km) limited-access state parkway on Long Island in the U.S. state of New York. The western terminus is at the Queens–Nassau County line, where the parkway continues westward into New York City as the Grand Central Parkway. The eastern terminus is at New York State Route 347 (NY 347) and NY 454 in Hauppauge. The parkway is designated New York S

entities.title: Southern State Parkway
entities.description: The Southern State Parkway is a 25.53-mile (41.09 km) limited-access highway on Long Island, New York, in the United States. The parkway begins at an interchange with the Belt and Cross Island parkways in Elmont, in Nassau County, and travels east to an interchange with the Sagtikos State Parkway in West Islip, Suffolk County, where it becomes the Heckscher State Parkway. The Southern State Parkwa

heading: Deaths
txt: Harold Sakata, American wrestler and actor (b. 1920)

entities.title: Harold Sakata
entities.description: Harold Sakata , born Toshiyuki Sakata  was a Japanese-American Olympic weightlifter, professional wrestler, and film actor. He won a silver medal for the United States at the 1948 Summer Olympics in London in weightlifting. He was also an actor, best remembered for his role as the villain Oddjob in the James Bond film Goldfinger (1964).

heading: Deaths
txt: Vladimir K. Zworykin, Russian-American engineer, invented the Iconoscope (b. 1889)

entities.title: Iconoscope
entities.description: The iconoscope was the first practical video camera tube to be used in early television cameras. The iconoscope produced a much stronger signal than earlier mechanical designs, and could be used under any well-lit conditions. This was the first fully electronic system to replace earlier cameras, which used special spotlights or spinning disks to capture light from a single very brightly lit spot.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Luis Buñuel

txt: Fred Waring, American television host and bandleader (b. 1900)

entities.title: Fred Waring
entities.description: Fredrick Malcolm Waring Sr. was a musician, bandleader, and radio and television personality, sometimes referred to as "America's Singing Master" and "The Man Who Taught America How to Sing". He was also a promoter, financial backer and eponym of the Waring Blendor, the first modern electric blender on the market.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bibhutibhushan Mukhopadhyay, Indian author, poet, and playwright (b. 1894)

entities.title: Bibhutibhushan Mukhopadhyay

txt: Bruno Kreisky, Austrian academic and politician, 22nd Chancellor of Austria (b. 1911)

entities.title: Bruno Kreisky
entities.description: Bruno Kreisky was an Austrian social democratic politician who served as Foreign Minister from 1959 to 1966 and as Chancellor from 1970 to 1983. Aged 72 at the end of his chancellorship, he was the oldest Chancellor after World War II. His 13-year tenure was the longest of any Chancellor in republican Austria.

entities.title: Chancellor of Austria
entities.description: The Federal Chancellor of Austria is the head of government of the Republic of Austria. The position corresponds to that of Prime Minister in several other parliamentary democracies. The term is gendered in the German language.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Britton, American physician (b. 1925)

entities.title: John Britton (doctor)
entities.description: John Bayard Britton was an American physician. He was murdered in Pensacola, Florida, by anti-abortion extremist Paul Jennings Hill. Britton's death was the second assassination of a Pensacola abortion provider in under a year and a half; he had replaced David Gunn after the latter's 1993 murder by another anti-abortionist.

heading: Deaths

entities.description:
The Chaos Computer Club (CCC) is Europe's largest association of hackers with 7700 registered members. Founded in 1981, the association is incorporated as an eingetragener Verein in Germany, with local chapters in various cities in Germany and the surrounding countries, particularly where there are German-speaking communities.

heading: Deaths
txt: Foday Sankoh, Sierra Leonean soldier, founded the Revolutionary United Front (b. 1937)

entities.title: Foday Sankoh
entities.description: Foday Saybana Sankoh was the founder of the Sierra Leone rebel group Revolutionary United Front (RUF), which was supported by Charles Taylor-led NPFL in the 11-year-long Sierra Leone Civil War, starting in 1991 and ending in 2002. An estimated 50,000 people were killed during the war, and over 500,000 people were displaced in neighboring countries.

entities.title: Revolutionary United Front
entities.description: The Revolutionary United Front (RUF) was a rebel army that fought a failed eleven-year war in Sierra Leone, starting in 1991 and ending in 2002. It later developed into a political party, which still exists today. The three most senior surviving leaders, Issa Sesay, Morris Kallon and Augustine Gbao, were convicted in February 2009 of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

txt: Rena Vlahopoulou, Greek actress and singer (b. 1923)

entities.title: Rena Vlahopoulou
entities.description: Irene "Rena" Vlahopoulou was a Greek actress and singer. She starred in theatre, musical, and Greek cinema productions, including The Gambler and The Countess of Corfu.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mike Reid, English comedian, actor, and author (b. 1940)

entities.title: Mike Reid (actor)
entities.description: Michael Reid was an English comedian, actor, author and occasional television presenter from London who is best remembered for playing the role of Frank Butcher in EastEnders and hosting the popular children's TV show Runaround. He was noted for his gravelly voice and strong London accent.

txt: Charles E. Wicks, American chemist and academic (b. 1925)

entities.title: Charles E. Wicks
entities.description: Charles Wicks is an Emeritus professor of chemical engineering at Oregon State University. His focus throughout his career has been mass transfer, and important aspect of chemical engineering along with momentum transfer and heat transfer.

txt: Tatiana Egorova, Russian footballer and manager (b. 1970)

entities.title: Tatiana Egorova
entities.description: Tatiana Egorova was a Russian footballer and manager. She played for CSK VVS Samara and Rossiyanka in the Russian Championship, and Turbine Potsdam in the German Bundesliga, and she was a member of the Russian national team, with whom she played the 1999 and 2003 World Cups.

txt: M. Caldwell Butler, American soldier, lawyer, and politician (b. 1925)

entities.title: M. Caldwell Butler
entities.description: Manley Caldwell Butler was an American lawyer and politician widely admired for his integrity, bipartisanship and courage. A native of Roanoke, Butler served his hometown and wider community first as a member of the Republican Party in the Virginia General Assembly (1962–1972) and later United States House of Representatives (1972–1983).

heading: Deaths
txt: Oliver Dragojević, a Croatian recording artist (b. 1947)

entities.title: Oliver Dragojević
entities.description: Oliver Dragojević was a Croatian recording artist, who was considered one of the most enduring musical stars and cultural icons in Croatia with a discography that spanned nearly five decades. His style blended traditional klapa melodies of Dalmatia, a coastal region in his native Croatia, with jazz motifs wrapped up in a modern production.

entities.title: Croats
entities.description: Croats, also known as Croatians, are a nation and South Slavic ethnic group native to Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. They are also a recognized minority in a number of neighboring countries, namely Austria, the Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Montenegro, Romania, Serbia, Slovakia, and Slovenia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Grant Thompson, American paramotorist and creator of the Youtube channel TKoR (b. 1980)

entities.title: Grant Thompson
entities.description: The King of Random (TKOR) is a YouTube channel created by Grant Thompson that conducts DIY projects and experiments, often involving large amounts of a single item. Thompson created the channel in 2010. Thompson died on July 29, 2019, in a paramotoring accident at the age of 38.
